newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil sets import quotas on Chinese clothing.
newsitem.headline: Brazil sets import quotas on Chinese clothing.

text.p: The Brazilian government will introduce quotas Friday for imports of textile goods from China, a trade official at the presidency said Thursday.
The quotas affect five categories of clothing and will halve the number of imported items compared with the number that entered Brazil in the 12 months to April this year, the spokesman said.
The quotas will remain in place for three years and may include goods from Hong Kong once the British colony returns to Chinese rule later this year, he said.
"The measures are aimed at protecting national industry," the official said.
Since 1995, Brazil's clothing industry has lost 30,500 jobs, sales have fallen 12 percent and factories are operating at 40 percent capacity, down from 78.5 percent, he said.

Under the quotas, China may export to Brazil each year 887,921 knitted shirts, 2.196 million men's bermuda shorts, 567,777 items of underwear, 1.995 million cotton shirts and 5.463 million synthetic and artificial shirts.
The official said the measures complied with safeguard rules included in the Uruguay round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, now the World Trade Organization.
He did not disclose the value of the imports which would now be prevented from entering Brazil.
